lg.l: A Man with expence and infinite Toyl
By Planting and dunging enobled his Soil
Where Fruits of the best the Tast did invite
And uniform order stil courted the sight
No degenerate Weed the ground did produce
But all things afforded for beauty and Use,
Till from Dunghil transplanted while yet but a seed
A Nettle rear'd up his inglorious head
The Gard'ner wou'd wisely have rooted him up
To stop the increase of a barbarous Crop
But the Master forbad him and after that fashion
Of foolish good nature, and blind moderation
For·bore him thro pity, and chose the much rather
To ask him some Questions how he came thither
Kind Sr: quoth the Nettle a Stranger I come
A Wanderer thrô Convenience I relinquisht my home.
Cause I wou'd not subscribe to a mistery dark
That the ······ of all Trees was the Jesuits Bark
An Erroneous tenet I know Sr: that you
No more than my self will allow to be true
To You I for refuge and sanctuary sue
There's none so renown'd for Compassion as You
And tho in some things I may differ from these
The rest of your beautifull and fruitfull Trees
As your digging and dunging my nature much harms
And I cannot comply with your Gard'ner in Forms
Yet I and our family after our fashion
Will peaceably stick to our own Education
Be pleas'd to allow us a place for to rest in
For the rest of your Trees we will not molest em
A kind shelter to me and protection afford
We'l do you no harm Sr I'le give you my word
The good-man was soon moved with a plaucible tale
So fraud on good nature does often prevail
He welcomes his Ghests gives him free Toleration
In the midst of his Garden to take up his Station
And into his Bosom does his Enemy bring
He little suspected the Nettle would stingX85-760L
